We will determine the current price of the stocks, to determine the current stock use the formulas:

$$\tag{1}P_0=\frac{D_0\cdot(1+g)}{(R-g)}$$

$$\tag{2}P_3=P_0\cdot (1+g)^3$$

$$\tag{3} P_{15}=P_0\cdot (1+g)^{15}$$

Where $P_0$ is the current stock price, $P_3$ is the current stock price after $3$ years, $P_{15}$ is the current stock price after $15$ years, $D_0$ is the current dividend, $g$ is the growth rate, $R$ is the rate of return.

Let's determine the current price by plugging the given values of $D_0,~g,~\text{and}~R$ into the formula $1$:

$$\begin{aligned}
P_0&=\frac{\$1.95\cdot(1+0.04)}{0.105-0.04}\\
&=\frac{\$2.028}{0.065}\\
&=\$31.20
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current price is $\$31.20$.

Let's solve for the price in $3$ years by plugging the value of $g$ and $P_0$ into the formula $2$:

$$\begin{aligned}
P_3&=\$31.20\cdot (1+0.04)^3\\
&=\$31.20 \cdot1.124864\\
&=\$35.10
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current price after $3$ years is $\$35.10$.

Let's solve for the price in $15$ years by plugging the value of $g$ and $P_0$ into the formula $3$:

$$\begin{aligned}
P_{15}&=\$31.20\cdot (1+0.04)^{15}\\
&=\$31.20 \cdot1.80094\\
&=\$56.19
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current price after $15$ years is $\$56.19$.
